images.caption: Hiroshima Castle
images.alt: A Japanese castle can be seen towering above trees in a leafy garden.

images.caption: Entrance to the grounds of Hiroshima Castle

images.caption: Hiroshima Gokoku Shrine

images.caption: Market stalls
images.alt: A market stall selling oranges beside the water.

images.caption: Hiroshima Peace Memorial
images.alt: The ruins of a building with the majority of its structure intact. The metal frame of its dome is exposed, and the walls stripped bare to expose brickwork. All windows are missing and some walls are collapsed.

images.caption: Enko river
images.alt: Modern building along the waterfront reflect in the water below.

images.caption: A path up Mt. Inari. The vermillion gates that frame the paths up the mountain are said to number over 10,000.
A bridge on the path up Mt. Inari
Fushimi Inari Taisha—the main Shinto shrine that sits at the base of Mt. Inari.
Itsukushima Shrine
images.alt: A large, ornate orange gate on a beach at low tide, with the sea and mountains behind.

images.caption: Itsukushima Shrine
images.alt: An angled view of a large orange gate on the beach, beyond some trees.

images.caption: The breach around Itsukushima Shrine
images.alt: A wide-angle view of a beach, surrounded by clear blue ocean and mountains.

images.caption: A five-storied pagoda on the island
Cheeky deer browsing the market stalls
Hotel view of Onomichi
images.alt: Trees and residential buildings of a seaside town, viewed from above, with an island close by across the water.

images.caption: The walk to the hilltop hotel with luggage in 30°C heat was interesting
images.alt: A steep, leafy hill with a a castle and hotel on top.

images.caption: Mukoujima Island, the first of seven islands that make up a 70KM bike trail
images.alt: An empty island road in front of clear blue water. Another island, accessible by bridge, is visible to the right.

images.caption: Innoshimao Bridge, leading to the second island in the trail
images.alt: A long bridge, high above the water, connects two islands rich with foliage.

images.caption: Another picture of the bridge will have to do, because we didn't get much further. Turns out 70KM through mountains in the heat is harder than it sounds. Thank god for the ferry.
images.alt: View of the entire bridge, showing a little of each of the two islands it connects.

images.caption: Tombori River walk, Dotonbori
images.alt: Shops and restaurants with illuminated signs line boardwalks either sides of a narrow river.

images.caption: View from Dotonbori Bridge
images.alt: Light displays on shops illuminate the water below.

images.caption: Dotonbori
images.alt: A very crowded, colourful shopping street

images.caption: Hotel room view
images.alt: A large red ferris wheel, surrounded by tall buildings lit up at night.

images.caption: Umeda, away from the main streets and towering buildings

images.caption: Kabukicho, Shinjuku

images.caption: Yoyogi Park viewed from the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building's free observation deck
images.alt: View of many tall buildings and a large green park from above.

images.caption: Sake barrels in Yoyogi Park
images.alt: A couple of hundred colourful sake barrels stacked in a display.

images.caption: Information about the sake barrels in Yoyogi Park
images.alt:
A plaque next to stacked sake barrels reads:

“Barrels of Sake Wrapped in Straw.

During the Meiji Era, Emperor Meiji, whose divine soul is enshrined here at Meiji Jingu, led the industrial growth and modernization of Japan by encouraging various industries and supporting technological development.

Due to their grace and virtue, Emperor Meiji and his consort, Empress Shoken, the beloved mother of our nation whose soul is also enshrined here, are held in the highest esteem by the Japanese people.

These sake barrels are offered every year to the enshrined deities by members of the Meiji Jingu Zenkoku Shuzo Keishinkai (Meiji Jingu Nationwide Sake Brewers Association) including the Kotokai, which has made offerings of sake for generations, as well as other sake brewers around Japan wishing to show their deep respect for the souls of Emperor Meiji and Empress Shoken.

In addition to stating our humble gratitude to all of the brewers who have so graciously donated their sake, we also pray for the continuous prosperity of the sake brewing industry and all the other industries maintaining Japan's traditional culture.

Meiji Jingu.”

images.caption: Hōzōmon gate, built in 942 CE, sits beside a five-storied pagoda

images.caption: Kabukicho, Shinjuku

images.caption: A capsule hotel—a cheap way to ensure a terrible night's sleep
images.alt: Rows of capsule beds, stacked two levels high. Each capsule has a square entrance and small blind to pull down for privacy. At less than 2m wide, there is space for one person to lie down in each.
